questions.text: A patient presented with 70% burns. A test was done on a sample collected from the burnt site as shown in the picture (oxidase test) probable causative organism is an obligate aerobe .What's the microbe?
questions.solution:
Psueudomoonas is gram negative bacilli, motile by polar flagellum, non capsulated but many stains have mucoid slim layer especially the organism which are isolated from cystic fibrosis patients.

They are obligate aerobe, colonies emit distinct musty, mawkish, earthy or sweet grape like odour or corn tocolike odour Cetrimide agar is selective media.

Oxidase test is shown in image, it is positive.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Staphylococcus aureus → Incorrect
    • Gram-positive cocci, facultative anaerobe.
    • Catalase-positive but oxidase-negative (does not match the oxidase test result).
    • Causes skin infections, abscesses, and toxic shock syndrome but is not the most common in burn wounds.
  • (Option C) Gram-positive cocci → Incorrect
    • The given bacterium is gram-negative bacillus, ruling this out.
  • (Option D) Streptococcus pyogenes → Incorrect
    • Gram-positive cocci in chains.
    • Catalase-negative, oxidase-negative.
    • Causes pharyngitis, cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis, but not a leading cause of burn wound infections.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common burn wound infection pathogen due to its resistance and adaptability.
  • Oxidase-positive, gram-negative bacillus, obligate aerobe = Pseudomonas.
  • Sweet grape/corn tortilla odor, pigment production, and growth on Cetrimide agar are diagnostic clues.

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids presented with nocturnal cough with chronic urticaria. BAL was obtained which showed certain larvae. What would it be?
questions.solution:
Strongyloides is an important opportunistic pathogen in immunocompromised host.

Habitat - Small intestine ( duodenum and jejunum)

Inf form - filariform larvae

Mode of inf - Penetration skin by filariform larva in soil

Strongyloides is parthenogenic worm, female is able to produce fertile eggs or larvae without meeting with males.

Clinically

Skin - urticaria, pruritus

Pulmonary - hemorrhages in alveoli, bronchopneumonia

Intestinal lesions - Necrotizing bowel disease, mild chronic colitis

Hyper infection - Paralytic ileus, G I bleed, Pulmonary hemorrhage

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Enterobius vermicularis → Incorrect
    • Does not cause pulmonary symptoms (affects perianal region).
    • Diagnosed by scotch tape test, not BAL.
  • (Option C) Ancylostoma → Incorrect
    • Hookworm larvae do not typically appear in BAL.
    • Causes iron deficiency anemia, ground itch, and cutaneous larva migrans, not nocturnal cough or hyperinfection syndrome.
  • (Option D) Capillaria philippinensis → Incorrect
    • Causes severe diarrhea and protein-losing enteropathy, not pulmonary symptoms.
    • Eggs and larvae are found in stool, not BAL.

Key Takeaways:

  • Steroid use + nocturnal cough + chronic urticaria + BAL with larvae = Strongyloides stercoralis.
  • Hyperinfection syndrome can occur in immunosuppressed individuals with severe GI, pulmonary, and systemic symptoms.
  • BAL helps diagnose Strongyloides larvae in pulmonary involvement.

questions.text: A truck driver presented with a painless, demarcated ulcer on penis with inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the best method of visualization to see the motility of the probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
This is a case of syphilis. Lab diagnosis of syphilis can be done by dark field microscopy. Other test are Direct fluorescent antibody test, Floculation test Kahn , VDRL, RPR, Complement fixation test. Treponema pallidum particle agglutination test, Treponema pallidum immobilization

Treponema pallidum hemagglutination assay, enzyme immune assay

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Light microscopy → Incorrect
    • Treponema pallidum is too thin to be seen on Gram stain or routine light microscopy without special staining.
    • Requires silver stain (Warthin-Starry stain) for visualization, but this does not show motility.
  • (Option C) Fluorescent microscopy → Incorrect
    • Fluorescent antibody tests (DFA-TP test) can be used to detect T. pallidum but do not show motility.
    • This is used in later stages of syphilis rather than primary syphilis diagnosis.
  • (Option D) Electron microscopy → Incorrect
    • Not used for routine clinical diagnosis due to cost and complexity.
    • Electron microscopy provides high-resolution images of bacterial structures but does not allow real-time observation of motility.

Key Takeaways:

  • Primary syphilis presents as a painless, well-demarcated ulcer (chancre) with inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • Dark field microscopy is the best method for detecting motile Treponema pallidum from lesion exudates.
  • Serologic tests (VDRL, RPR, FTA-ABS) are useful for secondary and tertiary syphilis diagnosis but not as reliable in primary syphilis.

questions.text: A child presented with history of pharyngitis and a swab was obtained and sent for culture. Swab should be discarded in which coloured bin?
questions.solution:
Biomedical waste guides are revised with time to time,  most recent guidelines are as below.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Blue bag → Incorrect
    • Used for glassware, metallic implants, and broken ampoules (non-infectious sharps).
    • Does not include culture swabs or microbiological waste.
  • (Option B) Red bag → Incorrect
    • Used for contaminated plastic items, such as IV tubes, catheters, syringes (without needles), and blood bags.
    • Microbiological waste does not go into the red bag.
  • (Option C) White bag → Incorrect
    • Used for sharps disposal (needles, scalpels, broken glass with blood contamination).
    • A swab does not count as a sharp.

Key Takeaways:

  • Microbiological waste, including culture swabs, is disposed of in a yellow bag.
  • Red bag → Contaminated plastic waste (IV tubes, catheters, syringes without needles).
  • Blue bag → Glassware (vials, broken ampoules).
  • White bag → Sharps (needles, broken glass with blood contamination).

questions.text: A patient was suspected of having brucellosis . serum sample was sent for standard agglutination test. It came negative initially but after dilution of serum sample the test was positive. What could be the reason for the initial negative test?
questions.solution:
There are two phenomenon for antigen antibody reactions. Prozone phenomenon and post zone phenomenon.’’ 

In prozone phenomenon there is antibody excess and in post zone phenomenon there is antigen excess. 

Antigen antibody reaction occurs when equal number of antigen binds with equal number of antibodies.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Postzone → Incorrect
    • Postzone occurs when antigens are in excess, preventing proper antigen-antibody complex formation.
    • In this case, the issue was antibody excess, not antigen excess.
  • (Option C) Complement inactivation → Incorrect
    • Complement inactivation affects complement-dependent tests like the complement fixation test (CFT), not agglutination tests like SAT.
  • (Option D) Antibodies → Incorrect
    • Antibodies are responsible for the test but do not explain the false-negative result.
    • The problem was excess antibodies (prozone effect), not their absence.

Key Takeaways:

  • Prozone effect = Excess antibodies → False-negative test → Dilution corrects it.
  • Postzone effect = Excess antigens → False-negative test → Needs repeat testing later.
  • Agglutination tests like SAT for brucellosis are prone to the prozone phenomenon.

questions.text: A male presented with urethral discharge as shown in the picture. What can be the cause?
questions.solution:
This case looks like gonococcal infection. Gonococci in gram negative diplococci.

It is one of sexually transmitted infection.

Patient complains of discharge from penis, pain in micturition.

Females there is discharge from cervix.

When we do gram stain of discharge, they will show gram negative diplococci.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Treponema → Incorrect
    • Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, which presents as painless genital ulcers (chancre) in primary syphilis, not urethral discharge.
    • It is a spirochete, not a Gram-negative diplococcus.
  • (Option B) Shigella → Incorrect
    • Shigella causes dysentery (bloody diarrhea), not urethritis or urethral discharge.
    • It is a cause of gastrointestinal infections, not STIs.
  • (Option D) Chlamydia trachomatis → Incorrect
    • Chlamydia can cause urethritis, but it produces a clear, mucoid discharge, rather than the thick, purulent (pus-like) discharge seen in gonorrhea.
    • Chlamydia is an intracellular bacterium, and Gram stain typically does not show organisms.

Key Takeaways:

  • Gonorrhea = Purulent (yellow/green) urethral discharge + Gram-negative diplococci on Gram stain.
  • Chlamydia = Clear/mucoid discharge, no bacteria visible on Gram stain.
  • Syphilis (Treponema) = Painless genital ulcer (chancre), no discharge.
  • Shigella = Gastrointestinal infection, not an STI.

questions.text: A female presented with profuse white vaginal discharge without any itching on 15th day of menstruation.what can be the reason?
questions.solution:
Leucorrhea is condition where white discharge comes from vagina of female.

It has many causes, some pathological some physiological.

In given condition it looks like physiological condition.

It is physiological because there is no itching along with white discharge.

Whenever it is pathogenic pt will complain itching along with white discharge

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Candidiasis → Incorrect
    • Candida (yeast infection) causes a thick, curd-like (cottage cheese) white discharge.
    • It is associated with intense itching and irritation, which is absent in this case.
  • (Option C) Trichomoniasis → Incorrect
    • Trichomonas vaginalis infection presents with a foul-smelling, frothy, greenish-yellow discharge.
    • It is accompanied by itching, burning, and irritation, which are not present here.
  • (Option D) Treponema → Incorrect
    • Treponema pallidum (syphilis) does not cause vaginal discharge.
    • Instead, it causes painless genital ulcers (chancre) in primary syphilis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Physiological leucorrhea = Normal vaginal discharge without itching, occurs around ovulation.
  • Candidiasis = Thick, curd-like discharge + intense itching.
  • Trichomoniasis = Frothy, greenish discharge + foul odor + itching.
  • Syphilis = Painless genital ulcers, no vaginal discharge.

Blood spill is common in hospital and labs.

It can be highly infectious.

Sodium hypochlorite is to be used to clean spilled blood.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Ethyl alcohol → Incorrect
    • Alcohol-based disinfectants (e.g., ethanol, isopropyl alcohol) are effective against many bacteria and viruses but do not destroy bacterial spores.
    • Alcohol evaporates quickly and is not suitable for large spills, especially when organic material (e.g., blood) is present.
  • (Option B) Chlorhexidine → Incorrect
    • Chlorhexidine is a good antiseptic for skin disinfection but is not effective for blood spills.
    • It has limited activity against viruses and spores.
  • (Option C) Formaldehyde → Incorrect
    • Formaldehyde is a strong disinfectant and sterilizing agent, but it is toxic, carcinogenic, and impractical for routine blood spill cleanup.
    • It is mainly used for preserving tissues or in closed sterilization systems.

Key Takeaways:

  • Best disinfectant for blood spills = Sodium hypochlorite (1% solution)
  • Alcohol is ineffective for blood spills due to rapid evaporation.
  • Chlorhexidine is mainly for skin antisepsis, not spill disinfection.
  • Formaldehyde is too toxic and impractical for routine use.

questions.text: A child presented with bloody stools and abdominal pain. What enrichment medium should be used to culture the organism
questions.solution:
The given case look like shigella dysentery because pt has blood in stool and abdominal pain.

Enrichment medium used for salmonella and shigella is selenite F broth.

Shigella are gram negative bacteria, classified under Enterobacteriaceae group.

All are not lactose fermenter except shigella sonnei that is late lactose fermenter.

Mannitol fermentation is used to differentiate spp of shigella

Shigella are non motile.

DCA is selective medium

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Alkaline Peptone Water → Incorrect
    • Alkaline Peptone Water (APW) is used to enrich Vibrio species (e.g., Vibrio cholerae), which require an alkaline environment for optimal growth.
    • It is not used for Shigella or Salmonella, which prefer neutral pH conditions.
  • (Option C) Sodium Hypochlorite → Incorrect
    • Sodium hypochlorite (bleach) is a disinfectant, not a culture medium.
    • It kills bacteria instead of promoting growth.
  • (Option D) Ethyl Alcohol → Incorrect
    • Ethyl alcohol is used in some bacterial isolation techniques (e.g., enrichment for Bacillus spp. and Mycobacteria), but it does not support the growth of Shigella or Salmonella.
    • Instead, it would kill most bacteria due to its denaturing effect on proteins and membranes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Selenite F broth is the best enrichment medium for isolating Shigella and Salmonella from stool samples.
  • Alkaline Peptone Water is used for Vibrio species, not Shigella.
  • Sodium hypochlorite and ethyl alcohol are disinfectants, not culture media.

questions.text: Wedge shaped hair perforation in the hair shaft is seen in
questions.solution:
Trichophyton infects Hair, skin and nail.

Microconidia are - abundant, arranged in clusters along hyphae

Macroconidia - relatively scanty, elongated with blunt ends _ pencil or cylindrical shaped

Wedge shaped hair perforation test is done for trichophyton mentagrophyte.

Hair perforation test consists of inoculating colonies of an organism into dish containing a small amount of water a few drops of yeast extract solution and some human hair dish is incubated at 30 degree celsius and after 7 days some hair are taken and kept on a slid with cover slip and observed under microscope. The test is considered positive if the hair has deep, narrow wedge shaped perforation in it.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Trichophyton rubrum → Incorrect
    • T. rubrum does NOT produce wedge-shaped perforations in the hair shaft.
    • Instead, it typically causes endothrix infection (inside the hair shaft).
    • It is urease-negative and usually appears red on reverse Sabouraud's agar.
  • (Option C) Microsporum canis → Incorrect
    • M. canis infects hair and skin, causing ectothrix invasion with fluorescence under Wood's lamp.
    • It does not show wedge-shaped perforation; instead, it forms large, thick-walled, spindle-shaped macroconidia.
  • (Option D) Microsporum audouinii → Incorrect
    • M. audouinii is a major cause of tinea capitis in children.
    • It typically causes ectothrix invasion, but does not produce wedge-shaped hair perforations.
    • It shows slow growth and does not produce conidia in culture.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hair perforation test helps differentiate Trichophyton mentagrophytes from T. rubrum.
  • Trichophyton mentagrophytes is hair-perforation positive (wedge-shaped perforations).
  • Microsporum species (M. canis, M. audouinii) do NOT produce wedge-shaped perforations but instead cause ectothrix hair invasion.

choices.text: Enveloped virus with single stranded RNA
Naked virus with single stranded RNA
Enveloped virus with double stranded DNA
Naked virus with double stranded DNA

questions.text: A child presented with bluish white spots in the mouth followed by a rash. What is the genome of the probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given sign symptoms suggest it is a case of measle.

Measle is enveloped virus. And has single strand of RNA in it.

Clinical feature

Prodromal stage - fever, coryza with sneezing and nasal discharge, redness of eye, lacrimation, photophobia

A day or two before the appearance of rash, Koplik spot appear on buccal mucosa opp 1st and 2nd lower molar tooth

Eruptive phase - maculopapular rash which begins behind the ear and spread rapidly in a few hour over the face and neck extends down the body.

Post measle stage - Wt loss, growth retardation , diarrhea

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Naked virus with single-stranded RNA → Incorrect
    • Measles is an enveloped virus, not naked.
    • Naked, single-stranded RNA viruses include Picornaviruses (e.g., Enterovirus, Rhinovirus), which do not cause measles.
  • (Option C) Enveloped virus with double-stranded DNA → Incorrect
    • Measles virus has an RNA genome, not DNA.
    • Examples of enveloped dsDNA viruses:
      • Herpesviruses (e.g., Varicella-Zoster Virus, which causes chickenpox, not measles).
      • Hepatitis B Virus (partially dsDNA).
  • (Option D) Naked virus with double-stranded DNA → Incorrect
    • Measles is enveloped and RNA-based, not a naked dsDNA virus.
    • Examples of naked dsDNA viruses:
      • Adenoviruses (cause conjunctivitis, respiratory infections).
      • Papillomaviruses (cause warts and cervical cancer).

Key Takeaways:

  • Measles virus is an enveloped, negative-sense, single-stranded RNA virus (Paramyxovirus family).
  • Koplik spots (bluish-white spots on buccal mucosa) are pathognomonic for measles.
  • The rash starts behind the ears and spreads downward.
  • Other enveloped ssRNA viruses include mumps, RSV, and parainfluenza (also Paramyxoviridae).

questions.text: A group of people had pastries late at night followed by bouts of vomiting early in the morning. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Case is of food poisoning. Typically occurred after eating pastries.

Incubation period is around 6 hrs. all eat at night and symptoms start in morning.

Food and incubation period suggests Food poisoning due to S aureus.

Pt can have nausea, vomiting, headache, abdominal pain.

Bacillus cereus food poisoning occurs mostly after eating fried rice.

Verotoxin does not cause food poisoning.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Vero toxin → Incorrect
    • Vero toxin (also known as Shiga-like toxin) is produced by Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) (e.g., E. coli O157:H7).
    • It causes bloody diarrhea (hemorrhagic colitis) and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) rather than vomiting.
  • (Option B) Bacillus cereus → Incorrect
    • B. cereus has two types of food poisoning:
      • Emetic type (vomiting, short incubation ~1–6 hours): Associated with fried rice (not pastries).
      • Diarrheal type (longer incubation ~8–16 hours): Causes watery diarrhea after eating meat, vegetables, or sauces.
    • Since the patient consumed pastries and not rice, S. aureus is the better choice.
  • (Option D) None of the above → Incorrect
    • The symptoms and timeline match Staphylococcal food poisoning, making "None of the above" incorrect.

Key Takeaways:

  • S. aureus food poisoning is caused by heat-stable enterotoxins.
  • Incubation period: 1–6 hours (rapid onset).
  • Symptoms: Vomiting, nausea, abdominal cramps (diarrhea is less common).
  • Commonly contaminated foods: Pastries, dairy products, mayonnaise-based salads, and meats.
  • B. cereus emetic type is similar but is typically linked to fried rice, not pastries.

questions.text: A patient presented with swelling on the scalp with pustules, erythematous lesions as shown. The patient has been petting a dog. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Keion is large pus filled sore caused by fungal infection. It usually appears on your scalp. It may look yellow or crusty, ooze pus, feel soft to touch and cause hair loss. Oral antifungal medication treat the fungal infection

Tinea capitis ( Dermatophyte fungal infection) cause kerion. Dermatophyte react with keroin in your hair, nail and skin.

The most common fungi that cause ringworm in scalp are

Microsporum canis

Trichophyton mentagrophyte

Trichophyton tonsurans

Trichophyton verrucosum

KOH, Culture and Wood’s lamp are used for diagnosis.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Abscess → Incorrect
    • Abscesses are localized collections of pus due to bacterial infections (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus).
    • They do not usually cause patchy hair loss or crusty, yellowish lesions as seen in kerion.
  • (Option B) Folliculitis → Incorrect
    • Folliculitis is an infection or inflammation of hair follicles, usually caused by bacteria (S. aureus) or fungal overgrowth.
    • It presents as small red or white pustules centered around hair follicles, without the large, boggy swelling seen in kerion.
  • (Option D) Epidermal cyst → Incorrect
    • Epidermal cysts are firm, slow-growing, non-inflammatory lumps filled with keratin.
    • They are not associated with pustules, erythema, or fungal infections.

Key Takeaways:

  • Kerion is a severe inflammatory tinea capitis caused by dermatophytes.
  • Zoophilic fungi (Microsporum canis) are commonly transmitted from pets (dogs, cats).
  • Clinical features: Boggy swelling, pustules, crusting, hair loss.
  • Diagnostic tests: KOH mount, fungal culture, Wood’s lamp examination.
  • Treatment: Oral antifungals (topical treatment alone is ineffective).

questions.text: What is the vector for a parasite which has kinetoplast in one of its morphological forms?
questions.solution:
The disease described here is leishmaniasis. It is transmitted by sandfly.

Leishmania occurs in two stages

Amastigote  ( Aflagellar stage) – In RE system of vertebrate host ( man dog or hamster)

Promastigote (Flagellar stage ):

A) in gut of sand fly

B) artificial culture

Leishmaniasis can present by many way

Visceral leishmaniasis – L donovani

Cutaneous leishmaniasis

Oriental sore – L tropica

Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis – L braziliensis.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) TseTse Fly → Incorrect
    • The Tsetse fly (Glossina) transmits Trypanosoma brucei, which causes African sleeping sickness.
    • Trypanosoma spp. are also kinetoplastid parasites, but Leishmania is specifically transmitted by sandflies.
  • (Option C) Anopheles Mosquito → Incorrect
    • Anopheles mosquitoes transmit Plasmodium spp., which cause malaria.
    • Plasmodium lacks a kinetoplast since it is an apicomplexan parasite, not a kinetoplastid protozoan.
  • (Option D) Triatomine Bug → Incorrect
    • The Triatomine bug (Kissing bug, Reduviid bug) transmits Trypanosoma cruzi, which causes Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).
    • cruzi is a kinetoplastid parasite, but it is not transmitted by sandflies.

Key Takeaways:

  • Kinetoplast is a mitochondrial DNA structure unique to kinetoplastid protozoa (Leishmania & Trypanosoma).
  • Leishmania is transmitted by sandflies (Phlebotomus/Lutzomyia).
  • Trypanosoma brucei (African sleeping sickness) → Tsetse fly.
  • Trypanosoma cruzi (Chagas disease) → Triatomine bug.
  • Plasmodium spp. (Malaria) → Anopheles mosquito (does NOT have a kinetoplast).

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilariae have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end:
questions.solution:
Microfilaria are different for different spp

Some are sheathed some are non sheathed.
Some have nuclei up to tail,

Some have no nuclei in tail.

Sheathed microfilariae - w bancrofti, loa loa, B malayi

Non sheathed microfilaria – M perstans, M ozzardi, M streptocerca, O volvulus

Sheathed microfilaria with nuclei up ot tail tip - B malayi, loa loa

Sheathed microfilaria with tail- tip free from nuclei - W bancrofti
Unsheathed microfilaria with nuclei upto tail tip – M perstans, M streptocerca

Unsheathed microfilaria with tail tip free from nuclei - M ozzardi, O volvulus

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Brugia malayi → Incorrect
    • Also sheathed, but nuclei extend to the tail tip (terminal and subterminal nuclei present).
    • Differentiation from W. bancrofti:
      • W. bancrofti → No nuclei at the tail tip.
      • B. malayi → Nuclei extend to the tip.
  • (Option C) Loa Loa → Incorrect
    • Also sheathed and has continuous nuclei to the tail tip (unlike W. bancrofti).
    • Causes Loiasis (African eye worm disease), transmitted by Chrysops (deer fly).
  • (Option D) Onchocerca volvulus → Incorrect
    • Unsheathed (lacks a sheath).
    • Causes Onchocerciasis (River blindness), transmitted by blackflies (Simulium spp.).
    • Nuclei do not extend to the tail tip, but it is not sheathed, so it is not a correct match.

Key Takeaways:

  • Wuchereria bancrofti → Sheathed, no nuclei at tail tip
  • Brugia malayi & Loa Loa → Sheathed, nuclei extend to tail tip
  • Onchocerca volvulus → Unsheathed, no nuclei at tail tip

questions.text: A pregnant woman, whose niece contracted varicella is in the same house was negative for serum antibodies for varicella, this would mean?
questions.solution:
Chicken pox is caused by varicella zoster virus

Incubation period is 10-21 days

Infection is acquired through respiratory tract via air droplets or rarely from conjunctiva.

Infectious period ( Communicable period) for chicken pox is 2 days prior to 5 days after onset of rash with very high secondary attack rate of 90 %.

Clinical feature has two stage

1. Pre eruptive stage - characterized by fever, back pain,malaise and shivering

2. Eruptive phase - Has characteristic rash with following feature

  • Superficial and unilocular ( Rash of small pox is deep seated and multilocular)
  • Symmetrical, mostly on flexor surface ( Rash of small pox usually affect extensor surface)
  • Centripetal distribution - (Rash of small pox has centrifugal distribution)
  • Affect axilla but spares palm and sole - ( small pox affect palms and soles but spares axilla)

Pleomorphic with appearance of all stages of rash simultaneously ( Rash is non omorphic in nature in small pox)

Dew drop on rose petal appearance ( Rash of small pox has umbilicated appearance )

Area of inflammation around the rash ( In small pox there is no inflammation around the rash)

Evolution of rash is rapid, scabs begin to form 4-7 days after rash (Evolution is slow , scab begin 10-14 after rash in small pox)

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) She is susceptible to zoster → Incorrect
    • Zoster (shingles) occurs due to reactivation of latent VZV in previously infected individuals.
    • Since she has never had chickenpox, she cannot develop zoster.
  • (Option C) She is immune to chickenpox → Incorrect
    • If she had serum antibodies, she would be immune.
    • However, she is negative for varicella antibodies, indicating no prior immunity.
  • (Option D) She is immune to zoster → Incorrect
    • Immunity to zoster comes from prior VZV exposure.
    • Since she has never had varicella, she cannot have immunity to zoster.

Key Takeaways:

  • No antibodies for varicella → Not immune, at risk for primary infection (chickenpox).
  • Chickenpox (Varicella) is the primary infection; Zoster (Shingles) is reactivation.
  • Pregnant women with no prior varicella immunity are at high risk and should receive varicella-zoster immune globulin (VZIG) if exposed to reduce complications.

questions.text: There is an outbreak of encephalitis in a community, according to universal immunization schedule, the route of administration of the vaccine for the likely infection is:
questions.solution:
Vaccine for Japanese encephalitis is to be given subcutaneously and in universal immunization program it is live vaccine.

2 0.5 ml doses, one week apart, to children six to twelve month of age.

Booster dose are given one year later ( 0.5 mk) and at 6-10 years of age ( 1 ml).

Similar type of outbreak can be done by N meningitidis. Its vaccine is killed and can be given subcutaneous. But it is not part of universal immunization immunization.

That s why answer is D live subcutaneous.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Killed subcutaneous → Incorrect
    • There is a killed inactivated JE vaccine available, but it is not part of the UIP.
    • UIP uses live-attenuated vaccine.
  • (Option B) Live oral → Incorrect
    • There is no live oral JE vaccine.
    • JE vaccines are either live subcutaneous or inactivated killed vaccines.
  • (Option C) Killed oral → Incorrect
    • Killed vaccines are never given orally for JE.
    • Killed JE vaccines (like inactivated Vero cell-derived vaccine) are given intramuscularly or subcutaneously, but not part of the UIP.

Key Takeaways:

  • Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccine in UIP is a live-attenuated vaccine (SA 14-14-2 strain).
  • Administered subcutaneously in endemic areas.
  • Killed vaccines exist but are not used in the UIP schedule.

questions.text: A known case of AIDs with productive cough and fever was found to have consolidation in the right infrascapular area with X ray showing right lower lobe consolidation with CD4 count of less than 55 per microlite. What is the most common cause of this?
questions.solution:
In AIDS when CD 4 cell count goes below 55 per microlitre. Many opportunistic infection can occur.

Here patient has consolidation in right infrascapular area and x ray showing right lower lobe consolidation. So patient has pneumonia.

This pneumonia is commonly caused by Pneumocystis jiroveci

Streptococcus pneumoniae is also right option, but incidence is less.

mycoplasma is wrong option.

S aureus is wrong option.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option A: Staphylococcus aureus - While S. aureus can cause pneumonia, it is more commonly seen in post-viral pneumonia or in association with lung abscesses and cavitary lesions. It is not the most common cause of pneumonia in advanced AIDS patients with a very low CD4 count.
  • Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae - S. pneumoniae is a leading cause of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals. However, in AIDS patients with severe immunosuppression (CD4 < 55), PCP is more common than bacterial causes, making Pneumocystis jiroveci the more likely answer.
  • Option C: Mycoplasma - Mycoplasma pneumoniae typically causes atypical pneumonia with diffuse interstitial infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation. It is more common in young, immunocompetent individuals and is not a frequent cause of pneumonia in advanced AIDS cases.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pneumocystis jiroveci is the most common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients with CD4 < 200, especially below 55.
  • While PCP typically presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, it can sometimes show lobar consolidation.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae remains a possible cause of pneumonia in AIDS but is less common than PCP in advanced cases.
  • Staphylococcus aureus and Mycoplasma pneumoniae are less likely in this scenario.

questions.text: History of painful swellings in the thigh, neck, groin, armpits with fever ,chills vector:
questions.solution:
Clinical feature look like plague. Xenopsylla cheopis transmits this

It is parasite of many mammalian species including rattus and human. Because of its parasitic nature, xenopsylla cheopis is a vector for plague, which transmits from rat to human.

Plague is caused by yersinia pestis

Gram negative coccobacilli

Non motile

Surrounded by slim layer

With giemsa or methylene blue stain. It shows bipolar staining - safety pin appearance.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option B: Phlebotomus orientalis - This sandfly is a vector for Leishmania donovani, which causes visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar). Kala-azar presents with fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and anemia, but not painful lymphadenopathy or buboes, making it an incorrect choice.
  • Option C: Chrysops silacea - This fly is the vector for Loa loa, a filarial parasite responsible for Loiasis (African eye worm disease). Loiasis presents with Calabar swellings (transient subcutaneous swellings) and migration of the worm across the eye, but it does not cause painful buboes or plague-like symptoms.
  • Option D: Glossina fuscipes - This tsetse fly is the vector for Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, which causes African sleeping sickness (Human African Trypanosomiasis, HAT). It presents with fever, lymphadenopathy (Winterbottom’s sign), and CNS involvement (sleep disturbances, confusion, coma) rather than painful buboes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Xenopsylla cheopis is the vector of Yersinia pestis, which causes plague.
  • Bubonic plague presents with painful lymphadenopathy (buboes), fever, and chills.
  • Other vectors (Phlebotomus, Chrysops, Glossina) are responsible for different diseases, none of which match the given clinical presentation.
